comments.commentBody:
Back in the day when tournaments were carried on ESPN2 and ABC (before ABC owned ESPN) all the tournaments were held at Putt-Putt courses and were sponsored in part by Putt-Putt. From the pictures accompanying the article, I assume that is no longer the case as the course pictured does not resemble any Putt-Putt course I remember. There are no boards along the sides to use in banking shots. I imagine it's much tougher to use the bricks.

For all the snarky comments here, just remember that there has been professional miniature golf in some form for at least the last 40 years, as I can remember tournaments being held back when I was in high school. The amount of money at stake may not be huge but it is more than enough to help someone pursue a hobby that they enjoy and that's really what it is all about. It's what sports used to be all about, and yes, I guess I'm showing my age.

So whose word would you believe? Some one who strong armed a store clerk and robbed it and then walks away as if nothing happened, or the police officer? If this 6'4" large man tried to pull out the cop from his car, he would very likely shoot in self defense. Let us wait for the results of the inquiry.
Unfortunately this philosophy often leads to writing that bores people to tears.

Kompletely koncur, Kootenaygirl. I made one attempt to get published (in the New Yorker, no less :-), and for a change, writing became self-conscious drudgery.

After that, I went back to writing purely for myself. Failure became impossible and writing became a daily joy again. I've since written and blogged over a thousand ultra-short "stories from life," and discovered that people really like them.

I agree. I write, frankly, because I *have* to; because the stories in my head won't leave me alone until I put words to them and put them on paper. I write because I want to know what happens next, because my characters interest *me* and I have great conversations with friends about them and their stories (I'm part of a couple online communities of amateur writers).

Honestly, the only way to fail at writing...is to not write. Anything else and you've accomplished SOMETHING.

An interesting perspective though one I do not share. I write almost every day because it is fun, it uplifts my spirit and I have a good time. Were I to succumb to all the negative thoughts portrayed in this story I would give up. Thank goodness I am blessed with positive thinking. Other writers will find this a most useful philosophy to contemplate. Cheers from Canada.

Lots of people apparently want the police to be transparent about their behavior, but not be transparent about Michael Brown's behavior.

Everyone, including the police, agree that A did not lead to B in this case. But it is relevant in establishing the tone and motivations that led to the confrontation in the middle of the street in Ferguson.

It will all work out in time-- it should be fairly easy to establish how many shots, where, whether they were in the back. I guess I don't understand why so many people are so quick to judge, when it is obvious that we don't have much of the story at this point. We should be somewhat skeptical of both sides until we know more-- but I guess that is old-fashioned.

This is a sweet and tongue-in-cheek story but I would worry this is not just perseverance and work ethic but OCD, and also the entourage thing is just bizarre.  Hope she is ok and that this is what she wants.

I'll bet not one of the people mocking this game could score more than 3 aces in a round, let alone the 15 in a row you'll need to actually win.

This game is like walking a tightrope. You can't deviate from perfection - or you lose.
I think we should stop evaluating race and focus on the individual. - Jon Girodes

I too question why the tape was released so late.

But the fact is the tape is out there and Brown's friend confirmed that it was Brown in the video.

I disagree that it is irrelevant or character assassination or "confuses" the issue. The video shows a violent young man committing a robbery. It's hard to see how that is not relevant to what may have happened an hour later with the officer. It's circumstantial support that he may have been violent with the officers. Doesn't mean Brown was violent with the officer. But regardless it's a welcome reminder for folks to wait for all the facts to come out before rushing to condemn Brown or the police.

Everyone's rushing to condemn the police for rushing to judgment and operating on the basis of stereotypes - let's be careful in protesting that we do not do the same.

"there is some evidence the young man robbed a convenience store"

so the video is only "some evidence". Maybe we should ask the roughed up store manager (ie., an apparant Indian, a "person of color") whether or not Brown paid for what he took out of the store.

It's actually about the decline in African-American players in MLB since 1981. Down from 18% to about 8.3%. At one point, a few years ago, there was one African-American player (and several black players of Dominican descent).

FYI: there were indeed a spate of articles in the 90s and early 00s about the racial makeup of the NBA, both from the angle of whether the league is "too black," and whether the hot pursuit of international players was actually an effort to "whiten" the league.

Love it when white people say we shouldn't note race.  Number of black kids playing baseball is declining.  Don't use the demographic of the MLB - look around at your neighborhood ball park - your high school team.  When I go check out a baseball game in socal - there aren't a lot of black folks in the stands.  Wake up.  For the Jackie Robinson team - get your game on - us black folks are followin you!

A fulsoe (thorough, complete) investigative report by the county prosecutor will take weeks. Officer Wilson's attorney will likely advise him not to make any statement before then. However, a friend of the officer's significant other did relate this account of what happened: http://danaloeschradio.com/alleged-friend-of-officer-darren-wilson-offer... I hope the Browns' attorney, Mr Crump, quickly gives out any information which can refute or confirm this account, such as the autopsy and toxicology results of the body released to the family.

I'm sort of confused.  Mr. Haley states, "Our mission is absolutely not turning our major league baseball'.  Mr. Haley goes on to state. "Our goal is to focus on getting as many kids involved as possible and get them to love the game as early as possible."  Mr. Rhoden seems to advocate some type of farm system as was described a couple weeks in an article about finding the next Andrew Wiggins.  That seems opposite to what Mr. Haley wants.    Did Mr. Rhoden ask any of the players what they want?  It does not appear so.   For Pete's sake, let these kids play baseball without adult burdens on their shoulders.

If Amazon cares about content creators, they should let content providers decide what the right price is and simply take a commission on the sale.   Some books might be best to be priced at $19.99 while others are best to be priced at $4.99.   If an author needs a book to sell for $19.99 to be worth the time to write it, and Amazon sets a cap at $9.99, then the book wont get written.   Then we all lose.  Hopefully a viable competitor like Google will take share from Amazon and then Amazon wont have the ability to dictate terms.

I wonder if Suarez would have bitten Roy Keane? Or Frank Riijkard (sp)? Or Diego Simeone? Or Patrick Viera? Or someone on their team?
Chiellini is a tough player and depended solely on the referee to mete out punishment. Even with 4 officials they saw nothing.
I understand that in a World Cup game no one wants to do anything stupid, but back in the not too distant past Suarez would have also paid a price on the pitch.

LG

@futbolista: Bites 2 and 3 were hardly the first controversies to envelop Suarez, and some of those were ealt with in these pages, and I have very clear recollection of withering criticism from Bakes, a longtime Liverpool fan, particularly about the Evra incident, which flared when he refused to shake hands the next time Liverpool played United. I recall then that Bakes wanted him off the side (which was admittedly a minority position). And that was before his breakout PoY season last year. Please be fair about it.
You have to be kidding, the man is ill and needs medical attention before he returns to the world of professional sports. How can anyone feel sympathy for his situation? Ridiculous.
Simple solutions: Ban Velcro from batting gloves?

I'm an old guy who has been watching baseball for a long time (55 years)...didn't they used to just drag the field once a game, or am I just senile.

And yes, I loved little Earl Weaver running/waddling out to the field, while snuffing a cigarette, to argue with the umpire. Yes, I think Showalter could still play first in a pinch?

Who escalated anything in any situation where the police are armed and the victim is unarmed, yet a gun is fired killing the victim?  If Brown was white this would not even be a discussion, and the police would not be investing so heavily in covering up for one of their own, they'd say he was "under stress and seeking medical help."

"Even if he had engaged in some criminal behavior, stealing a box of cigars is not a capital crime and had this young man lived, he might have matured into a productive member of society."

Maybe you should ask the store manager that we see being roughed up at the end of the video what his thoughts on the matter were. Somehow I have a feeling he would disagree.

Cops haven't learned to "use their weapons to disable rather than kill" because 1) pistols can't be used with such discerning accuracy in stressful situations; 2) even assailants who are fatally wounded can continue their attack for quite a while--let alone those who have been "shot in the foot." An excellent rule of thumb is, shoot to kill or don't shoot at all. This is what all police are, or should be, trained to do.

we do not know all the facts yet.  Let the investigators do their job and put it through the courts.  If the deceased did have his hands up and the cop shot him i agree that would be murder, but let the facts come out first.

shooting of an unarmed person multiple times from a distance of 20+ feet while said person is in a submissive posture is indefensible. I dont care if Brown broke the officers jaw. They officer was not in immediate danger.

Crimes have consequences, but the death penaltty was not the punishment for any crime Brown committed that day at least that we or the police are aware of. Even if that was the punishment there is due process

The possibility that Officer Wilson was unaware that Brown was a robbery suspect does not make the robbery irrelevant.  If Brown did commit the robbery, he might have been afraid that Wilson knew he was the suspect, which might have given Brown a motive to resist arrest from the very beginning of his encounter with Wilson.  Even he witnesses friendly to Brown paint a picture of the incident that is consistent with Brown having resisted arrest from the beginning up until the moment when Brown turned with his hands up.  Brown's resisting arrest would not justify the killing, but it might make the killing something less than murder, and might give the angry community a reason to temper its anger at Wilson, if not at the local police force for the way it acted after the killing.
It was robbery. And it wasn't Brown's only violent crime. Last November, he was arrested and charged with a violent burglary. And he has a sealed juvenile record. Will "Anonymous" find it?
Really.  If strong arm robbery is minor in your eyes, what would Mr. Brown have had to have done to lose your sympathy?

Cowboy, in the scenario you describe the star is a white teenager, who would be slapped on the wrist for misbehaving & probably given hours of community service or some such to atone for his sin.
In this case, however, the actor is black. As all too many letters in this thread make clear, it's the difference between day & night. This boy is not merely an aggressive teenager feeling his oats & shoplifting a pack of cigarillos. He is a criminal & a thug best hustled quickly off to prison. That a cop killed him with his hands up means only that he got what he deserved.
So depressing! Is there nowhere in the U.S. a majority for making the punishment fit the crime---irrespective of skin color? Are white people so incapable of seeing that there is a black-white dichotomy in the justice meted out for the same crimes? Are white people so insensitive to language that they are unaware that the words they choose also depend on the race of the parties involved?

A few commenters have probably already mentioned this, but if he had not shoved the merchant, a theft of that amount of $ would be considered petty theft/the lowest level misdemeanor in most if not all jurisdictions in the U.S. If a first offense, that would likely mean having to take a class, provide $ restitution to the merchant, paying a fine, and possibly some community service. The physical contact takes the charge up a notch or two, but would be considered relatively minor based on the video.
